Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the Convergence between Engagement Patterns, User Perceptions, and Course Outcomes in Science Massive Open Online Courses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) open up an opportunity to extend educational access to a diverse range of people. However, the opportunity presented by MOOCs may also exacerbate currently existing educational gaps by engaging only motivated students whose goals align with the course design. With digital instruction becoming increasingly popular, there is an increasing need to understand both instructors' and students' interpretation of the online learning environment. This study aims to uncover ways to better support learners in digital environments through an investigation of how learners use and perceive MOOCs. The investigation will be informed by usage data and interviews with Japanese students. Given that most studies on MOOCs have been conducted in North America, this study will address the need for more evidence overseas in order to highlight the extent that MOOCs are interpreted in the same manner beyond the borders of the institution delivering the course.

This study will look specifically at single-platform MOOCs, which more closely resemble traditional approaches to education rather than multi-platform connectivist experiences. This study will use both cluster analysis and sequential pattern mining to find usage patterns that characterize the work of strong and weak students, as defined by the quality of written work in forum and assignment participation. The researcher will be engaged in ongoing discussions with each course instructor to ensure that ratings of students' work align with instructor categorizations of quality (high, moderate, or low). Semi-structured interviews with both the instructors and the students will inform the whether the emergent categories of usage patterns after consistent between both instructor expectations and student perceptions. From the emerging patterns and interviews, this study will draw a cross-cultural comparison to existing empirical results on North American MOOCs. If the same usage patterns are found, then this study suggests a consistent theme for MOOCs. If this study yields different results, then the findings suggest alternative approaches to MOOCs and online courses.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Distance education in Japan has been and still is primarily television and radio broadcast based. However, the introduction of massive open online courses (MOOCs) generated movement among higher education institutions who had previously not given serious consideration to online education as part of their long-term strategy (Aoki, 2015). In 2013, Kyoto University and Tokyo University were the first two Japanese universities to release English-taught MOOCs on major MOOC platforms. In the same year, universities and corporate institutions in Japan joined together to form the Japan Massive Open Online Course (JMOOC) Consortium (Yamada, 2015).

As a 2017 Japan EAPSI Fellow, I had the opportunity of work with Dr. Toru Iiyoshi and the Center for the Promotion of Excellence in Higher Education (CPEHE) team at Kyoto University. Kyoto University recently released several science MOOCs that were freely available to the public, and the university was in the process of creating more courses. During the funding period, I analyzed data from one of the MOOC courses taught by the university. I worked with members of the CPEHE to get a better understanding of the course structure and production flow. Preliminary findings helped guide my interviews with MOOC instructors and students. From the discussions with CPEHE members and instructor- and student-interviews, I adjusted my analyses accordingly. I also had the opportunity to witness the different stages (such as planning, filming, and reflecting) of MOOC production at Kyoto University. Being able to view first-hand the careful thought that Kyoto University faculty put into creating a MOOC helped validate my interview results and analysis findings.

As part of the data analyses, this study used two different ways of coding student activity in an online course. One method replicated the coding scheme of a different study by Kizilcec, Piech, and Schneider (2013). Like the original study, it found a group of students who completed the course (completing), a group of students who started the course by gradually decreased activity (disengaging), and a group of students who were active only early in the course (sampling). Unlike the original study, however, it did not find a group of students who were simply auditing the course. The second coding scheme took into account the number of different days that a given student logged in and the amount of time that the students spent in the course. Similar groups of students were found using the second coding scheme. Most students who categorized as highly active were completing students. Most students who categorized as inactive were sampling students.

This study distinguishes groups of students based on their weekly usage patterns. It suggests that prior findings on types of student engagement in MOOCs can be replicated in courses taught by universities new to open and online education.
